awd_titl_txt: EAGER: The Role of Emotion in Risk Communication and Warning: Application to Risks of Failures to Update Software
awd_abstract_narration: End-users' online behavior can significantly affect the reliability and security of next-generation software systems. For instance, skipping repeated requests to update software or ignoring security warnings while visiting unknown websites, while extremely dangerous, are not uncommon. Although end-users' actions (or inactions) often open up the opportunity for cyber-attacks, the lack of emotional appeals and poor design of the current software update/warning messages are to blame to a large extent for such risky behavior, which is addressed as follows. First, this project identifies the limitations of the current software update/warning messages from an affective-cognitive perspective, and addresses the shortcomings by incorporating emotional appeals that command attention and evoke emotions more effectively. Also, message designs are changed adaptively based on the context and user's past behavior to counter the habituation-effect. Finally, to increase the compliance rate, this project develops emotional education and inoculation strategies that enable users to recognize and avoid the temptation associated with risky online behavior. Successful completion of this project will greatly advance the understanding of the impact of emotion on the decision making process in regards to safe online behavior, and will revolutionize the way software vendors communicate the risks of running vulnerable software and warn users. The research findings will be published in premier academic venues, and will be disseminated through project website. Research agendas will be integrated with the curriculum development activities. Existing programs at UConn will be leveraged to promote diversity and engage students from underrepresented communities.

por.por_cntn:
Software companies constantly try to identify performance/security vulnerabilities and release fixes promptly. However, users often ignore/delay recommended updates, potentially compromising the reliability and security of computing systems. To better understand the underlying reasons behind users’ negligent behavior, this project first investigated users’ attitudes and perceptions regarding software update and warning messages and identified that participants are commonly hesitant to apply updates, even though they report caring about computer security and privacy, indicating inconsistent mental models. To broaden the scope of the work focusing on software update behavior, next we considered multiple security advices (i.e., software update, use of a password manager, use of 2FA, changing passwords frequently) and approached the question of “why do some follow security advice, while others do not," using empirical data collected and analyzed for that purpose. We modeled decision-making using a cost/benefit, rational decision making framework. From there, we expanded to include the concept of risk, which is expected to be key factor in security decisions. Our study revealed significant gaps in mental models between followers and non-followers of security advices in terms of risk/cost/benefit perceptions. Importantly, our study showed that each group (i.e., followers and non-followers) generally believes that they are doing the “right” thing. In other words, followers of a certain security advice perceived the benefits of complying and risks of not complying as higher than non-followers do, identifying possible avenues to persuasion through risk communication.

As emotions can both enhance and undermine effective decision-making, in addition to rational factors, we examined discrete emotions anticipated when pop-up warnings appear, including specific positive, negative, individualist, and prosocial emotions based upon affective neuroscience. Forty-five emotions associated with receiving warnings associated with failing to update software, both in relaxed online sessions and sessions involving time and attention pressures, were assessed for underlying measurement structure. We identified four reliable latent factors for relaxed (R) and pressured (P) conditions: Positive Affect, Anxiety, Hostility, and Loneliness. P conditions were higher in reported Anxiety, Hostility, and Loneliness and lower in reported Positive Affect. Men reported higher feelings of Hostility and Loneliness; women reported higher Anxiety.

Finally, to encourage adoption of good cybersecurity behavior, we looked at emotional education and inoculation technique that calls for users to be introduced to the emotions they may feel around a decision involving risks before they are faced with it, thereby promoting mindful processing of risks. Specifically, we designed video interventions explicitly addressing users’ emotional response to security advices and decisions targeting three different cybersecurity advices as case studies (e.g., applying software updates, using two-factor authentication, and using a secure password manager). Content for the videos was developed based on prior work and our study findings, with some of the interventions incorporating emotional inoculation content. To assess the impact of the interventions on sampled users, we used a survey that measured their awareness, perceptions of benefits, costs, and risks, and emotions around the target advice. It was hypothesized that the emotional inoculation intervention would have a larger and longer lasting impact on these variables compared with the basic approach. Results of this study supported this, calling for further study and application of emotional inoculation towards altering cybersecurity behavior.

In addition to advancing our understanding regarding the impact of emotion on the decision making process in the context of software update and cyber security behavior, and reaffirming the importance of addressing emotions to promote sustainable cyber behavior, this project provided excellent opportunities for students to explore the areas of risk communication and persuasion in cyber security context. This grant resulted in top-tier conference and journal articles and enabled one student to complete his PhD degree. Furthermore, the grant supported the graduate student to present research findings at a top-tier conference venue. To reach a wider community, the PI presented the research outcome at multiple venues such as the Center for Applied Cybersecurity Research, Indiana University, Worcester Polytechnic Institute (WPI), and the New England Security Day (NESD) event.
